title: Christie’s New York Offers Sneak Peek of Pieces From Only Watch Charity Auction
text:
Text size

Christie’s New York is hosting a preview of 50 one-of-a-kind timepieces created for next month’s Only Watch charity auction, as the collection stops in the city on Oct. 16 and 17 on its global pre-sale tour.

Every other year, watch brands of all sizes contribute a unique piece to be sold to benefit Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) research. Luc Pettavino, president of the Association Monégasque contre les Myopathies, which supports scientific and medical research on DMD, and former organizer of the Monaco Yacht Show, founded the auction in 2005 after his late son Paul was diagnosed with muscular dystrophy.

“I didn’t want to be angry or to feel like a victim when my wife and I discovered our son Paul had Duchenne muscular dystrophy,” Pettavino said in a message on the Christie’s website. “I needed an idea through which we could raise a lot of money. I wanted to have what I hoped would be a consistent amount of money to plough into research.”

Pettavino underscores that the pieces are auctioned without fees and that neither he nor the brands receive any financial compensation. As it embarks on its eighth edition, Only Watch and its supporting brands have raised almost $40 million with 100% of the funds going toward finding a cure.

With an estimate of about US$2.5 million to US$3 million, Lot 28 is by far the most valuable. Patek Philippe’s super-complicated Grandmaster Chime reference 6300A-010 will be the first and only Grandmaster Chime ever produced in stainless steel, making it a coveted collector’s piece.

Created to mark the brand’s 175th anniversary in 2014, the Grandmaster Chime features a remarkable 20 complications, including the brand’s first grande sonnerie in a wristwatch. Other chiming modes include a petite sonnerie, a minute repeater, and two patented world firsts: an acoustic alarm that strikes a preselected time and a date repeater that sounds the date on demand.

“The steel case allow the grand-sonnerie to literally ‘sing’ in a way I have never heard a Patek before,” says John Reardon, Senior International Consultant, Christie’s Watches. “The metal and size of the watch allows magic to happen in terms of the sound.”

The watch’s special two-sided case swivels back and forth so you can choose to show the Time side in rose gold with a hand-guillochéd hobnail center or the Calendar side in black ebony inscribed with the words: The Only One. “What surprises me is the use of the words 'The Only One' on the dial,” Reardon says. “We have never seen this before and will never see it again.”

De Bethune and Urwerk have teamed up to create the Moon Satellite. Christie's

Creative independent brands De Bethune and Urwerk have teamed up to create the Moon Satellite, merging signature mechanisms and aesthetic codes from each. The visionaries behind both brands collaborated on the one-off URDB01 caliber developed for the auction. The mirror-polished blued titanium case’s floating lugs, crown positioned at 12 o’clock, and high-precision spherical moon phase point to its De Bethune lineage, while the unorthodox case design and radical satellite time indication channel the sci-fi essence of Urwerk. Lot 15 is estimated to sell for about US$120,866 to US$151,083.

“The spirit of collaboration between these two great independents can be felt when one holds the watch,” Reardon says. “If you are a fan of innovation and technical prowess, this is the watch for you, and Only Watch is quite fortunate to be the catalyst of such a historical collaboration.”

Other highlights include F.P. Journe’s Astronomic Blue with a prototype movement and tantalum case estimated to sell for about US$300,000 to US$400,000 and a mixed-metal version of Audemars Piguet’s new Code 11.59 by Audemars Piguet Tourbillon Openworked in white and pink gold with an estimate of about US$190,000 to US$240,000.

While most of the watches fall in the five- and six-figure range, Tudor’s trendy Black Bay Ceramic One, Lot. 44, has an approachable estimate of about US$4,400 to US$5,500. The very first ceramic Black Bay looks particularly modern and stealthy in all matte black.

From New York, the exhibition will move on to Asia—Tokyo, Singapore, Hong Kong, and Taipei—before returning to Geneva for the auction on Nov. 9 at the Four Seasons Hotel des Bergues.
description: Leading the sale to benefit Duchenne muscular dystrophy research is a Patek Philippe Grandmaster Chime, estimated at US$2.5 million to US$3 million
